the-image-orientation.name: image-orientation
the-image-orientation.summary: The image-orientation CSS property specifies a layout-independent correction to the orientation of an image.
the-image-orientation.title: image-orientation

the-image-rendering.name: image-rendering
the-image-rendering.summary: The image-rendering CSS property sets an image scaling algorithm. The property applies to an element itself, to any images set in its other properties, and to its descendants.
the-image-rendering.title: image-rendering

the-image-rendering.name: image-rendering
the-image-rendering.summary: The image-rendering attribute provides a hint to the browser about how to make speed vs. quality tradeoffs as it performs image processing.
the-image-rendering.title: image-rendering

the-object-fit.name: object-fit
the-object-fit.summary: The object-fit CSS property sets how the content of a replaced element, such as an or
the-object-fit.title: object-fit

the-object-position.name: object-position
the-object-position.summary: The object-position CSS property specifies the alignment of the selected replaced element's contents within the element's box.
the-object-position.title: object-position

gradients.name: gradient
gradients.summary: The <gradient> CSS data type is a special type of <image> that consists of a progressive transition between two or more colors.
gradients.title: <gradient>

image-values.name: image
image-values.summary: The <image> CSS data type represents a two-dimensional image.
image-values.title: <image>

cross-fade-function.name: cross-fade
cross-fade-function.summary: The cross-fade() CSS function can be used to blend two or more images at a defined transparency.

chrome.notes: Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

chrome_android.notes: Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

opera.notes: Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

opera_android.notes: Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

safari.notes: Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.
Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

safari_ios.notes: Support for the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.
Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

samsunginternet_android.notes: Support for the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

webview_android.notes: Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

edge_blink.notes: Supports the original dual-image with percentage implementation only.

cross-fade-function.title: cross-fade()

element-notation.name: element
element-notation.summary: The element() CSS function defines an <image> value generated from an arbitrary HTML element. This image is live, meaning that if the HTML element is changed, the CSS properties using the resulting value are automatically updated.
element-notation.title: element()

conic-gradients.name: conic-gradient
conic-gradients.summary: The conic-gradient() CSS function creates an image consisting of a gradient with color transitions rotated around a center point (rather than radiating from the center). Example conic gradients include pie charts and color wheels. The result of the conic-gradient() function is an object of the <gradient> data type, which is a special kind of <image>.
conic-gradients.title: conic-gradient()

linear-gradients.name: linear-gradient
linear-gradients.summary: The linear-gradient() CSS function creates an image consisting of a progressive transition between two or more colors along a straight line. Its result is an object of the <gradient> data type, which is a special kind of <image>.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.

notes: Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.

notes: Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer 5.5 through 9.0 supported gradients via a proprietary filter: -ms-filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.Gradient().

opera.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

opera_android.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

linear-gradients.title: linear-gradient()

radial-gradients.name: radial-gradient
radial-gradients.summary: The radial-gradient() CSS function creates an image consisting of a progressive transition between two or more colors that radiate from an origin. Its shape may be a circle or an ellipse. The function's result is an object of the <gradient> data type, which is a special kind of <image>.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer 5.5 through 9.0 supported gradients via a proprietary filter: -ms-filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.Gradient().

safari.notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

safari_ios.notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

radial-gradients.title: radial-gradient()

repeating-gradients.name: repeating-conic-gradient
repeating-gradients.summary: The repeating-conic-gradient() CSS function creates an image consisting of a repeating gradient (rather than a single gradient) with color transitions rotated around a center point (rather than radiating from the center).
repeating-gradients.title: repeating-conic-gradient()

repeating-gradients.name: repeating-linear-gradient
repeating-gradients.summary: The repeating-linear-gradient() CSS function creates an image consisting of repeating linear gradients. It is similar to linear-gradient() and takes the same arguments, but it repeats the color stops infinitely in all directions so as to cover its entire container. The function's result is an object of the <gradient> data type, which is a special kind of <image>.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.

notes: Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.

notes: Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer 5.5 through 9.0 supported gradients via a proprietary filter: -ms-filter: progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.Gradient().

opera.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

opera_android.notes: Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in repeating-linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(linear,…) function. It is more limited than the later standard version: you cannot specify both a position and an angle like in repeating-linear-gradient(). This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.
Considers <angle> to start to the right, instead of the top. I.e. it considered an angle of 0deg as a direction indicator pointing to the right.

repeating-gradients.title: repeating-linear-gradient()

repeating-gradients.name: repeating-radial-gradient
repeating-gradients.summary: The repeating-radial-gradient() CSS function creates an image consisting of repeating gradients that radiate from an origin. It is similar to radial-gradient() and takes the same arguments, but it repeats the color stops infinitely in all directions so as to cover its entire container, similar to repeating-linear-gradient() . The function's result is an object of the <gradient> data type, which is a special kind of <image>.

firefox.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

firefox_android.notes: Before Firefox 36, gradients weren't applied on the pre-multiplied color space, leading to shades of grey unexpectedly appearing when used with transparency.
Since Firefox 42, the prefixed version of gradients can be disabled by setting layout.css.prefixes.gradients to false.

safari.notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

safari_ios.notes: Safari 4 was supporting an experimental -webkit-gradient(radial,…) function. This old outdated syntax is still supported for compatibility purposes.

repeating-gradients.title: repeating-radial-gradient()

image-notation.name: image
image-notation.summary: The image() CSS function defines an <image> in a similar fashion to the <url>() function, but with added functionality including specifying the image's directionality, specifying fallback images for when the preferred image is not supported, displaying just a part of that image defined by a media fragment, and specifying a solid color as a fallback in case none of the specified images are able to be rendered.

firefox.notes: The -moz-image-rect() function supports fragments as of Firefox 4.

firefox_android.notes: The -moz-image-rect() function supports fragments as of Firefox 4.

image-notation.title: image()

image-set-notation.name: image-set
image-set-notation.summary: The image-set() CSS function notation is a method of letting the browser pick the most appropriate CSS image from a given set, primarily for high pixel density screens.

safari.notes: Support for url images only and x is the only supported resolution unit. See bug 160934.

safari_ios.notes: Support for url images only and x is the only supported resolution unit. See bug 160934.

image-set-notation.title: image-set()

typedef-image.name: image
typedef-image.summary: The <image> CSS data type represents a two-dimensional image.
typedef-image.title: <image>
